title: Bansjore block
text:
Bansjore block (also spelled Bansjor) is a <a href="Community%20development%20blocks%20in%20India">CD block</a> that forms an administrative division in the <a href="Simdega%20subdivision">Simdega subdivision</a> of <a href="Simdega%20district">Simdega district</a>, in the Indian state of <a href="Jharkhand">Jharkhand</a>. 
History.
Gumla district was carved out of Ranchi district in 1983. Till 30 April 2001, Simdega was a subdivision of Gumla district and was made a separate district from that date. 
Maoist activities.
According to a <a href="Press%20Information%20Bureau">PIB</a> release in 2018, Simdega is one of the thirty districts most affected by <a href="Left%20wing%20extremism">Left wing extremism</a> in the country (along with twelve other districts of Jharkhand). “The terrain of the district is very tough and geography is favourable for naxal activities.” All police stations in the district are well fortified and equipped to handle the situation. Community policing activities are being prioritised to involve the simple village folk. 
<a href="Hemant%20Soren">Hemant Soren</a>, Chief Minister of Jharkhand, has claimed, in September 2021, that as a result of the effective action against <a href="Far-left%20politics">Left wing extremism</a>, the “presence of hardcore Maoists has been limited to mainly four regions, namely Parasnath Pahar, Budha Pahar, Tri-junction of Seraikela-Khunti-Chaibasa district in Kolhan division and some of the areas along the Bihar border”. 
Geography.
Simdega district lies in the south-western part of the <a href="Chota%20Nagpur%20Plateau">Chota Nagpur Plateau</a>. It has been described as “a dissected upland of ancient crystalline rocks” The general elevation of the district is above mean sea level. The landscape is formed of hills and undulating plateau. The Major rivers of this area are <a href="Sankh%20River">Sankh</a>, <a href="Deo%20River">Deo</a>, Girwa, and Palamara. 
Bansjore CD block has an area of 151.07 km2.<a href="Bansjore%23Police%20station">Bansjore</a> police station serves Bansjore CD block. The headquarters of Bansjore CD block is located at <a href="Bansjore">Bansjore</a> village. 
Bansjore CD block is bounded by <a href="Jaldega%20block">Jaldega</a> CD block on the north and the east, Nuagaon andKuanmunda CD blocks in Sundargarh district of Odisha on the south, and <a href="Thethaitangar%20block">Thethaitangar</a> CD block on the west.
Demographics.
Population.
According to the <a href="2011%20Census%20of%20India">2011 Census of India</a>, Bansjore CD block had a total population of 25,519, all of which were rural. There were 12,856 (50%) males and 12,663 (50%) females. Population in the age range 0-6 years was 3,827. <a href="Scheduled%20Castes%20and%20Scheduled%20Tribes">Scheduled Castes</a> numbered 886 (3.47%) and <a href="Scheduled%20Castes%20and%20Scheduled%20Tribes">Scheduled Tribes</a> numbered 21,840 (85.58%). 
Literacy.
According to the 2011 census, the total number of literate persons in Bansjore CD block was 13,334 (61.47% of the population over 6 years) out of which males numbered 7,726 (70.60% of the male population over 6 years) and females numbered 5,608 (52.17% of the female population over 6 years). The <a href="Literacy%23Gender%20disparities">gender disparity</a> (the difference between female and male literacy rates) was 18.43%. 
 census, literacy in Simdega district was 67.59%. Literacy in Jharkhand was 67.63% in 2011. Literacy in India in 2011 was 74.04%. 
See also – <a href="List%20of%20Jharkhand%20districts%20ranked%20by%20literacy%20rate">List of Jharkhand districts ranked by literacy rate</a> 
Language and religion.
According to the "Population by Mother Tongue 2011" data, in the Bansjore subdistrict, <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a> was the mother-tongue of 11,464 persons forming 44.92% of the population, followed by (number of persons and percentage of population in brackets) <a href="Mundari%20language">Mundari</a> (10,186/ 39.91%), <a href="Kharia%20language">Kharia</a> (2,568/ 10.26%), <a href="Kurukh%20language">Kurukh</a> (314/ 1.04%), and persons with other languages as mother-tongue (243/ 0.95%). Persons with Hindi as mother-tongue included 10,979 persons having <a href="Sadri%20language">Sadri</a>/ <a href="Sadan%20people">Sadan</a>, 300 persons having <a href="Nagpuri%20language">Nagpuri</a> as mother-tongue. Other languages include 207 persons having <a href="Odia%20language">Odia</a> as mother-tongue. 
<a href="Hindi">Hindi</a> is the official language in Jharkhand and <a href="Urdu">Urdu</a> has been declared as an additional official language. 
According to the "Population by Religious Communities 2011" data, in the Bansjore subdistrict, <a href="Christians">Christians</a> numbered 14,304 and formed 56.05% of the population, followed by (number of persons and percentage of population in brackets) <a href="Hindus">Hindus</a> (5,529/ 21.67%), <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> (50/ 0.20%), persons who did not state their religion (26/ 0.10%), and ‘Other religious communities’ (5,610/ 21.98%). 
<a href="Scheduled%20Castes%20and%20Scheduled%20Tribes">Scheduled Tribes</a> numbered 424,407 and formed 70.78% of the total population of Simdega district. Within the scheduled tribes the more populous tribes were (percentage of ST population in 2011 in brackets): <a href="Munda%20people">Munda, Patars</a> (33.61%), <a href="Kharia%20people">Kharia, Dhelki Kharia, Dudh Kharia, Hill Kharia</a> (25.42%), <a href="Oraon%20people">Oraon, Dhangar Oraons</a> (20.13%), <a href="Gondi%20people">Gonds</a> (5.77%) and Lohras (5.32%).
Economy.
Overview.
The "District Census Handbook, Simdega," mentions, “Simdega is one of the least developed districts in the country... As per the survey conducted for the year 1997 –2002 five-year plan more than 60% of population is below poverty line.”Another report says that 80% and over of the population of Simdega district were in the <a href="Below%20Poverty%20Line">BPL</a> category in 2004–2005.In 2011-12, the proportion of BPL population in Simdega district came down to 38.26%.According to a study in 2013 (modified in 2019), "the incidence of poverty in Jharkhand is estimated at 46%, but 60% of the scheduled castes and scheduled tribes are still below poverty line."
Livelihood.
In Bansjore CD block in 2011, amongst the class of total workers, cultivators numbered 9,555 and formed 76.90%, agricultural labourers numbered 1,349 and formed 10.86%, household industry workers numbered 355 and formed 2.86% and other workers numbered 1,166 and formed 9.38%. Total workers numbered 12,455 and formed 48.69% of the total population, and non-workers numbered 13,094 and formed 51.31% of the population.
Infrastructure.
There are 19 inhabited villages in Bansjore CD block. In 2011, 19 villages had well water (covered/ uncovered), 19 villages had hand pumps, and all villages have drinking water facility. 1 village had post offices, 4 villages had sub post offices, 18 villages had mobile phone coverage. 19 villages had pucca (paved) village roads, 7 villages had bus service (public/ private), 7 villages had <a href="Auto%20rickshaw">autos</a>/ modified autos, 5 villages had taxi/ vans, 15 villages had tractors. 3 villages had bank branches, 15 villages had <a href="public%20distribution%20system">ration shops</a>, 12 villages had <a href="Vidhan%20Sabha">assembly</a> <a href="Polling%20place">polling stations</a>. 
Agriculture.
According to the "District Census Handbook, Simdega," the rural population depends mainly on agriculture for a living. Agriculture in Simdega is in a very primitive state. The district has about 32% of forested area. Out of 1,34,024 hectares of cultivable land only 4,669.83 hectares of land is irrigated. Agriculture is mainly dependent on seasonal rain. The average rainfall of the district is 1100-1200 mm but much of it remains unutilised. 
Backward Regions Grant Fund.
Simdega district is listed as a backward region and receives financial support from the <a href="Backward%20Regions%20Grant%20Fund">Backward Regions Grant Fund</a>. The fund, created by the Government of India, is designed to redress regional imbalances in development. As of 2012, 272 districts across the country were listed under this scheme. The list includes 21 districts of Jharkhand. 
Education.
Bansjore CD block had 12 villages with pre-primary schools, 19 villages with primary schools, 7 villages with middle schools, 3 villages with secondary schools, 1 village with senior secondary schools, all villages have educational facility. 
Healthcare.
Bansjore CD block had 1 village with <a href="Primary%20Health%20Centre%20%28India%29">primary health centres</a>, 2 villages with primary health subcentres, 1 village with maternity and child welfare centre, 1 village with allopathic hospital, 2 villages with dispensary/ health centres, 1 village with family welfare centre, 4 villages with medicine shops. 
References.
